etymologies: late 18th century; earliest use found in James Burgh (1714–1775), educationist and author. From ancient Greek πτωχο-, combining form (in e.g. πτωχοποιός drawing beggarly characters) of πτωχός (adjective) poor, (noun) beggar (from the stem of πτώσσειν to shrink, cringe, go begging, probably ultimately from the same Indo-European base as ancient Greek πέτεσθαι to fly) + -cracy

definitions: A government elected by or consisting of the poor; (in extended use) poor people considered as a class.
